seg.seg: the noble one does not care about my conduct either. [But] anytime she stretches her arm when she serves me, she pulls [me] onto her lap, as it were. The jewelry upon her breasts hardly moves,
[But] anytime she stretches her arm when she serves me, she pulls [me] onto her lap, as it were. (cf 9; 258)
[Wenn] sie den Arm reckt, indem sie [mich] bedient, zieht [wtl. nimmt] sie [mich] gleichsam in [ihren] Schoß.
[When] she reaches out [her] arm in attending [to me], she pulls [lit. takes] takes me onto [her] lap, as it were.
Das Geschmeide auf ihren Brüsten bewegt sich kaum, es hebt sich eben nur.
The jewellery upon her breast hardly moves, it just so slightly heaves.
it merely is lifted a little. But even though she is shy, she nevertheless gladdens my heart with love. 1. Who may she be?
Aber [wenn sie] auch schüchtern [ist], [so] macht sie doch mein Herz von Liebe froh.
But even [if she is] shy, she still gladdens my heart with love.
Who may she be? Is she the sister, the daughter, or the wife, or the servant of the mechanic, or has she come to him as a guest, just like me? (cf 9; 46)
Wer [ist] sie wohl? Ist sie des Mechanikers Schwester [oder] Tochter oder Frau oder Dienerin?
Who [may] she [be]? Is she the mechanic's sister [or] daughter or wife or servant?
Is she the sister, the daughter, or the wife, or the servant of the mechanic, or has she come to him as a guest, just like me? (But)
(But) a guest would not have been charged to pay honour to [another] guest. (cf 9; 258)
a guest would not have been charged to pay honour to [another] guest. But very much the mechanic has shown his trust in me
that he has left a girl so beautiful alone with me. And the painter [says to himself]: By my passion she shall (not be aggrieved(?)); he yawns
Darauf [denkt] der Maler: "Durch (meine) Leidenschaft soll (sie nicht geschädigt(?)) sein", er gähnt [und] macht Miene, die Hand zu strecken.
Thereupon the painter [thinks]: "Through (my) passion (she) shall (not) be (harmed(?))", he yawns [and] is about to stretch [out his] hand.
and is about to stretch out his hand. Thus (he thinks) to himself while looking at the girl.
|| In the A.-tune: || But no! Love has arrived in person, in order to confuse me by his own face ... What if perhaps

What if perhaps she had seated herself right before [lit. manifestly] me to honour me? As long as I don't speak to [lit. honour] her with heart-felt affection [lit. honour], my dream [that] this gentle one serves me, does not get spoilt yet.

Wenn sie offenbar etwa nur, [um] mich zu verehren, vor mir sitzen (sollte), [so] stört diese Zarte, [mich] bedienend, [von sich aus] auch nicht meinen Traum, solange ich zu dieser nicht die Sprache des Herzens spreche.

When, apparently only to venerate me, she (should) sit before me, this tender one, attending [to me], will not disturb my dream [of her own accord], as long as I do not speak to her in the language of the heart.
she had seated herself right before [lit. manifestly] me to honour me? As long as I don’t speak to [lit. honour] her with heart-felt affection [lit. honour], my dream
[that] this gentle one serves me, does not get spoilt yet. 1. Again he thinks: Seeing the great danger,
Wiederum denkt er: "Im Hinblick auf große Gefahr ist ja hier Klugen nicht erlaubt, zu zehnerlei Frauen Liebe zu äußern ..."
Again he thinks: "With regard to great danger wise ones are not allowed here to speak [their] love to ten kinds of women ... "
the wise ones are not allowed here to profess love to ten kinds of women. Thus it is said: to
the royal spouse, to the father’s spouse, to the spouse of a general, to that of a relative, to that of the teacher, to an exceedingly
adulatory woman, to a woman thinking of profit, to a woman available to many, and mainly (to a beautiful)
